title: Thousands demand Scottish independence as they march through Edinburgh
text:
Scottish independence supporters march through Edinburgh during an All Under One Banner march. (Picture: PA)

The streets of Edinburgh were lined with bands, dogs, and countless Saltire flags today as thousands marched for Scottish independence.

Organisers estimated a turn-out of 100,000 people, coming from groups all over the country and united in backing the country’s separation from the UK.

The march set off from Holyrood Park at 1pm and proceeded along the Royal Mile.

Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon tweeted her support for the All Under One Banner (AUOB) protest, stating that she could only be there ‘in spirit’.

She wrote: ‘Good luck to everyone marching for independence in Edinburgh later.

The AUOB group has been launching a series of marches that have escalate in size and scale (Picture: PA)

Good luck to everyone marching for independence in Edinburgh later. I’m not able to be there in person today, but I will be with you in spirit. Have a great day. And be in no doubt – independence is coming. #indyref — Nicola Sturgeon (@NicolaSturgeon) October 5, 2019

‘I’m not able to be there in person today, but I will be with you in spirit. Have a great day. And be in no doubt – independence is coming. #indyref.’

Protester Gemma MacFadyen, 34, said she has backed Scottish independence since she was a child but has become frustrated with protesting over the years.

She said: ‘To be honest, after the last referendum I was a bit deflated and disenfranchised and I was not going to be taking part anymore.

‘But recently after a trip to the west coast of Scotland I’ve been re-inspired – so I’m here today.

Musicians kept spirits high on the autumnal Edinburgh day (Picture: PA)

Bikers joined in the call for independence (Picture: PA)

Many of them donned full face paint (Picture: PA)

‘I’ve not really been caught up in the whole Brexit debate, I’m not bothered about that.

‘But I am for another independence referendum, as soon as possible – it should’ve been ages ago.’

Scottish independence pressure group AUOB formed in October 2014, one month after the in/out referendum came down in favour of remaining in the UK and EU.

It aims to raise the profile ‘of the need of an independent Scotland’ and bring together different independent activists and organisations from across the country.
